title: The Table of Nations
summary: Genesis 10 presents the genealogy of Noah’s sons—Shem, Ham, and Japheth—detailing the spread of nations after the flood. It shows how the earth was repopulated.

faq.question: Why is this genealogy important?
faq.answer: It shows how all nations trace back to Noah’s sons and sets the stage for future biblical history.

faq.question: Who were the sons of Noah?
faq.answer: Shem, Ham, and Japheth—each became the ancestor of various nations.

faq.question: Why does the Bible care about nations and where people came from?
faq.answer: In Bible times, a person’s identity was tied to their family and land. This chapter helps connect the ancient world to the story of God’s people later on.

faq.question: What does it mean when it says people had their own languages and lands?
faq.answer: It means that over time, as families grew, they moved apart and developed their own cultures, languages, and places to live. This sets the stage for the story of the Tower of Babel in the next chapter.
